intro: Symplocos blepharodes, commonly known as the bellflower symplocos, is a shrub native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Ericaceae and is characterized by its small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale pink. The plant has simple, alternate leaves that are elliptical in shape and often have a slightly hairy texture. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest undergrowth. The flowers bloom in clusters and are pollinated primarily by insects, contributing to its ecological role in its native habitat.
